The first month of the Roman calendar was originally March but was eventually changed to January. They were both 31-day months, so the Ides would have been 1/15 not 1/13.

Always found this piece of trivia interesting (probably more interesting for those of us who know Hindi/Urdu/Persian)-

Seersucker comes from the Persian words shir and shakar, literally meaning "milk and sugar", from the gritty texture ("sugar") on the otherwise smooth ("milk") cloth.

Sam Corbin:  "62A. This [Competitive poker?] is an object that pokes, not a card game. The answer is √âP√âE, which is a lance used in fencing."

When I fenced in high school and college, we never referred to an epee (nor foil nor saber) as a "lance." To cite Google's AI, which I think is correct in this specific case:  "No, an epee is not a lance; an epee is a fencing sword with a large guard, used for thrusting attacks in the sport of fencing, while a lance is a long, pointed spear typically used by cavalry on horseback in warfare, making them very different weapons with distinct purposes and designs."

Further:  "The word "epee" comes from the French word √©p√©e, which means "sword". The word "lance" comes from the Roman word lancea, which means "javelin"."
Harder than most recent Thursday puzzles.

‚Ä¢ IMS ‚Äî I thought it had to be dMS. I‚Äôm on Slack (and pretty much every other non extremist social media platform) but I‚Äôve never had occasion to slide into someone‚Äôs IMS. I wonder why they use that retro (circa AOL) term?

And I‚Äôm with you, @Heidi, about 13A. I take it a step further and say I‚Äôm agog that this clue made it into the NYT crossword. In fact, I‚Äôm going to try to include the emoji here üçÜ and see if it passes the EMU. Either way, the adult talk has entered the crossword community ü§£.
Nice one, interesting how much mileage a puzzle can get themed around just one word. Enjoyed it!

Fun puzzle! Really easy turned into really hard several times. I confidently filled in TIN (what other element has 3 letters?). Hmm, that can't be right because 17D is unlikely to start with two Ts. I wasn't sure about the first T, because music isn't my language, but that term is in crosswords often enough. Next up was confidently filling in both DADDYlonglegs and WHYTHElongface. 

I was suspicious that trickery was afoot when IGUANA seemed likely (but didn't fit with my crosses), then knew it was when SEERSUCKER fell into place. Thank you for that long word that couldn't be anything else!

Then FGS only elicited "huh?" Final goals? Do people actually say FG in conversation? And then the SW corner took a while to untangle. The happy music was a nice surprise.
For the trickiness on some of the words and the game of the longer answers, I think the clues could have used some edits. Also hajji not haji. 50 on a table. Whole puzzle felt a bit loose.
2025 Griddy contender!

Congratulations, Dan, on the long-awaited publication of this fun puzzle. It gave me a long-lasting smile.

Color me amazed and delighted.

It is so very strange how the tentacles that *something* is going on seep into your neural networks and something doesn't seem quite right.  You can't identify anything, but a lot of letters are showing up duplicated (and that's weird) and a letter I thought would be leading a string is actually the second, and what the H-E-DOUBLE TOUTHPICKS is going one here... (emus?  ok?)

It's even more amusing when it comes a day early.

There was so much stuff I did not know in this otherwise quite simple puzzle - including place names and brands - that I broke down and looked that restaurant up... And that spoiled the theme for me. I know and understand that's on Polish and very un-American me, but I can't say I particularly enjoy when that happens.

The trick was quite cool - I would ideally prefer if  gimmicks were limited to Thursdays, but I can appreciate a good one on Wednesday, too. Still, how things developed for me because of a brand lookup has me a bit sore...

So, this was probably a nice puzzle and I suffered simply because I wasn't really its intended solver.

I‚Äôm fairly new here. Is it common for a gimmick to be unannounced? I would have thought the clue to 15D would read ‚Äî ‚ÄúWhat a stereotypical bartender asks after a horse walks into a bar (and a clue to solving‚Ä¶)‚Äù and then those connected by the theme are highlighted, as I‚Äôve seen in other puzzles. Not this time. I found the this frustratingly not enjoyable at all because I didn‚Äôt know I was supposed to be figuring out the trick. 

And I really don‚Äôt think ‚ÄúIMS‚Äù is a thing anymore. ‚ÄúInstant message‚Äù is what we used to do on AOL twenty five years ago. These days any message in Slack, Instagram, WhatsApp, literally any modern app, is always called ‚ÄúDMS‚Äù for direct messages.

Having ‚ÄúWHY THE LONG FACE‚Äù perfectly fit for 15D was a devilish misdirection that (combined with the day of the week) screwed me up for a long time today. It was amusing to see how many potential crosses seemed off vertically by one letter (‚ÄúIt has to be AGRA, right? MERIT would make sense. Surely it‚Äôs SEERSUCKER‚Ä¶‚Äù) before the light eventually switched. Not to mention the number of answers I ruled out in the NW because I knew you wouldn‚Äôt have two consecutive I‚Äôs, J‚Äôs etc. So close to the right answer, and yet so far!

All that to say, I can‚Äôt fault the constructor! This was a nice one, even if I suffered more than I expected on a Tuesday night. I echo the other commenter who said this was harder than most recent Thursdays.

Finishing this one seemed like a SSHHOOTT for awhile‚Ä¶ not because of the trick (which I caught on to once I had J O H N in every other square), but because of the many obscure clues. At least, they were unfamiliar to me. 

SERA? AIR? ELIS? FINE? C‚Äômon, the short words are supposed to be easy! They put OYSTERS in a po‚Äô boy? Ew, no thanks. SNES? I gotta learn those gaming consoles! Is a munchkin really an ELF? I was proud to get EPEE right away‚Ä¶ but probably only because I see it all the time.

Still, the fun of figuring out the trick went a WWAAYY toward easing my minor frustrations. It was a satisfying one to finish.
This puzzle is gimmickry squared. I loathe gimmickry.

Just curious‚Ä¶Any idea why the creator (or editors) chose to orient the puzzle with the themes going down. It could equally have been reversed. Do you think there‚Äôs a sense that Long is more vertical and Wide is more horizontal? I would think that would necessarily be true of Tall but not necessarily Long.

1A was a heck of a start if you don't know the Elvis title (DIDJA).  I would have caught the theme way sooner if I did lol. Instead I had a long period of second guessing correct answers until it finally clicked lol.  

I needed a lot of crosses in non-theme areas too.  I don't know if that was due to ambiguity of clue or lack of breakfast but I did feel satisfied when I finished. I enjoyed the theme and graphic very much :)
That took me TTIIMMEE !
That was fun!

Wednesdays used to be my sometimes challenging but doable puzzle, while Thurs-Sat were my "learning" puzzles where I leaned into the hints and tried to gain skills. (Sundays are usually doable for me, maybe with a hint tor two.) The past two Wednesdays have felt oddly tricky. I agree with one commenter that there should have been a "revealer." Please give us usual slope up to the difficult days. :-)

I can understand that this was a great and perhaps even an easy puzzle for some people.  Alas, I am too slow in the uptake and too ignorant of popular culture to get a buzz from this one.  For example, the real ‚Äúdaddylonglegs‚Äù fit perfectly so I assumed the few crosses that I had entered were wrong.  I had to consult the Wordplay column to figure out what was going on quite early in my attempted solve.
Fun puzzle. Took me a while--slightly above twice my average time. I agree with those who say it was Thursday ish.

I would love this puzzle any day of the week. 

Did I look over at my husband halfway through and say, "Wait. It is Wednesday, right?" Yes. 

Did I solve it within one second of my average Thursday time? Also yes.

Was it all worth it when I figured out the trick and was able to fill in 3 long answers all at once? Absolutely, yes!

Yup, I thought there would be a lot of comments, and that is why I popped in.

This was tough. Those double letters made me very nervous for a long time, and I unentered a number of correct answers because of them.

But having some experience here, I was on the look out for a revealer or some other clue that there was a trick. Also, I have heard a bunch of times here that when things just won't fit, look for something, like a rebus maybe. 

It took me a long time to catch on. But after seeing a large number of double letters in a variety of places, I started to look at that angle, and sure enough, it all fell into place.

My time was 57:50. I am a mid-tier solver here, I believe. Many of my recent Thursday puzzle solves have been in the mid-30-minute range. 

Oh yeah. I thought this was a very good puzzle, but I understand how some of the newer solvers found it to be over the top.

Still, I don't think the constructor was showing off. I think they were just practicing their craft, and boy are they good at it.

Whew, this one blind-sided me.  Took twice my average time for wednesday and about a thursday average.  Didn't expect any tricks, and this was a hard one. Just now figured out what Haji meant, thought it must be star trek.  No hints, only the one lookup so not too bad.  Just slow.

3 mins over my usual Wed solve but I‚Äôm not mad about it - in fact I love the ‚ÄòThur lite‚Äô of this puzzle!

Utterly ridiculous, not fun and flat-out unfair.  I‚Äôm baffled how anyone would make sense of the repeated letters.  I refuse to play further crosswords here after this ‚Äî if you‚Äôre going to use repeated letters or other f-ed up nonsense, there needs to be clues of some sort or instructions. i actually think the construction is quite good... but to not include any sort of hint or tip is a pretty gross miscalculation. when there are real answers that fit, you end up just frustrating the solver. what an incredibly avoidable and dumb way to ruin what could've been a great puzzle.

if i've said it once...... a puzzle should want to be solved. this most certainly did not.

Sorry, not a fan despite the cleverness, and anyone who says the "horse pun" was a cleverly-hidden clue rather than a bad dad joke is just making excuses. That effect at the end (on the app, at least) was worth the gnashing of teeth required to get through this puzzle! 
Felt like a Thursday to me.
‚ÄúLong face‚Äù being the same amount of letters as ‚Äúffaaccee‚Äù set me back ten years on figuring this one out

Finally got around to doing the puzzle today. Wait! What is happening here?! I double checked the day of the week twice üòÜ I‚Äôm always up for a good rebus and this didn‚Äôt disappoint. I confidently entered WHY THE long facE before that didn‚Äôt work. And I figured out it had to be long john SILVER, but J was my second letter. Then the light bulb moment ‚Ä¶üí° I get it!! Love when that happens. Thank you, Dan, for a most enjoyable Wednesday afternoon solve.

Very fun!! 

Tricky puzzles, when I have to be in my actual office, are always tricker because I tend to work on them in fits and spurts to fit with my work and coworkers so it took a while to get it amongst the distractions. But I hadn't really gotten it. 

So it took a bit longer to  get that it wasn't a rebus in the double letter in a box way. (I first tried just the phrases with long spelled out, so it seemed like that kind of rebus.) This was better! 

I'd probably have caught onto it faster if I'd know the Elvis song.. 

Either way, it was a lot of fun and thankfully only induced smiles, instead of a coma. 

I really liked the EPEE clue... competitive poker. Ha! I liked the UMP clue too. Fun to have common answers showing up with more clever clues. 

So, for anyone else who enjoyed this puzzle, IAGREE!

I wonder if the editors need to get their calendars checked! Been seeing a lot of Friday puzzles that take me substantially longer than the adjacent Saturday and now we‚Äôre seeing Thursday puzzles on Wednesdays. üòÜ

I appreciate that you‚Äôre  trying to digest a lot of scholarship here, but I have to nitpick at least a couple of things: 

While Rome‚Äôs ‚Äúinheriting‚Äù of many traditions from the Greeks is a truism I myself am fond of invoking, a wholesale borrowing of a calendar did not happen. Even after Numa‚Äôs time, the Greeks weren‚Äôt exactly an administratively unified entity‚Äîthey had wildly different regional calendars that wouldn‚Äôt have been easy to copy even if Rome had wanted to. It‚Äôs not like the Greeks had a single ‚Äúofficial‚Äù calendar handbook lying around for a young Rome to adopt.

That and, while there are numerous primary sources chronicling the evolution of the Roman calendar, I‚Äôm not aware of any ancient historians discussing any Greek connection at length. I‚Äôm open to looking at evidence to the contrary, of course, but you‚Äôd have to start us off with a couple of cites. 

The other thing is your assumption no one really knows why certain months numbered x many days. Many historians have written on the subject extensively, as a matter of fact. I‚Äôm going to grossly simplify it here: The lunar cycle is 29.5 days. Since even numbers were inauspicious, Roman priests had to get that average from 29- and 31-day months, while also preserving the maximum number of nundiae for certain months‚Äîand of course serving their own political ends.
